details.title: Safety Achieved by the Safe Failure Fraction (SFF) in IEC 61508

authors.affiliation: Tokyo Univ. of Marine Sci. & Technol., Tokyo

p: Itaru Yoshimura (M'03) (born on 14th Feb. 1975 in Japan, IEEE No.41455054) received the M.S. degree in Systems Engineering from Tokyo University of Mercantile Marine, Tokyo, and joined Nippon Kaiji Kyokai in 1999. He received the Ph.D. degree in Systems Engineering from Tokyo University of Mercantile Marine, Tokyo in 2004. His research interests include system reliability, system safety, risk assessment of technological systems, and functional safety.

p: Yoshinobu Sato (M'90) (born on 4th Aug. 1948 in Japan, IEEE No.01194307) is a Professor in the Dept. of Maritime Systems Engineering at Tokyo University of Marine Science and Technology (TUMST). Prior to joining TUMST, he was a Professor at Tokyo University of Mercantile Marine. He received the M.S. degree in Mechanical Engineering from Waseda University, Tokyo, and the Ph.D. degree in Systems Engineering from Kyoto University, Kyoto. His research interests include system reliability, system safety, risk assessment of technological systems, and functional safety. He has supervised 7 Ph.D. dissertations concerning functional safety at both Universities. He is the co-author of several books on functional safety (in Japanese), and published more than 60 journal articles as well as over 100 refereed conference articles. He was the Chairman of the IEEE Reliability Society Asia, and the Tokyo Chapter; and was the first Chairman of IEEE Reliability Society System Safety Technical Committee. Currently he is an IEC Expert on the revision of IEC 61508 and IEC 61511, and the Chairman of IEC TC56 Dependability Japan National Committee.

authors.name: Yoshinobu Sato

details.abstract: The present paper examines the effect of safe failure fraction (SFF) constraints on hazardous-event rates, and discusses the validity of the SFF constraints in IEC 61508. First, the safe states are categorized into three types of states, and overall systems involving safety-related systems are classified into six types of systems based on the safe-state categorization, and the completeness of trips. Next, state-transition models for the systems where the effect of SFF is the greatest are presented, and the hazardous-event rates are analysed for the systems. Then, it is found that, when the effect of the SFF constraints is positive, it is negligible; and when it is negative, it is not negligible for safety. Thus, we recommend that the application of the SFF constraints to the standard should be put on hold.

The standard defines the SFF as the ratio of the average rate of safe failures plus dangerous-detected (DD) failures of the subsystem to the total average failure rate of the subsystem [16].

Other examples of conflicting safe states are [17]: 1) activating an airbag is the safe state for a collision of automobiles, but rather a dangerous state for typical driving; 2) an unmanned airborne vehicle is landed using a parachute such that if the parachute door fails to open then the vehicle crashes, and if the door open spuriously then the vehicle may land outside of the landing area, both of which are very dangerous options; and 3) the parachute is connected to the vehicle by a mechanical device called a “discard”, which must keep the connection until the vehicle is landed, and then must release the connection as soon as it is landed.
